name: Kepler-118
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-118 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-118 is a star with 1.085 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.09 times its radius. It is located 1904.13 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-118 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-118 b

Kepler-118 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 7.52 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-118.

The mass of Kepler-118 b is 4.85 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-118 b is 1.96 that of Earth. At 4.85 Earth masses, Kepler-118 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-118 c

Kepler-118 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.14 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 20.17 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-118.

The mass of Kepler-118 c is 128.18 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-118 c is 7.68 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, Kepler-118 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-118, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
